contentrichtext.text: '''Red Clay Creek''' is a {{convert|13.6|mi|km|adj=mid|-long}} [[tributary]] of [[White Clay Creek]], running through southeastern [[Pennsylvania]] and northern [[Delaware]] in the [[United States]].<ref name=NHD/><ref name=courseconflict/> As of 2000, portions of the creek are under wildlife habitat protection. ==Course== The East and West branches both rise in [[West Marlborough Township, Chester County, Pennsylvania]], near the hamlet of Upland, and flow south through [[Kennett Square, Pennsylvania|Kennett Square]] before uniting just north of the Delaware border. The stream enters Delaware near the town of [[Yorklyn, Delaware|Yorklyn]] and flows southward through [[New Castle County, Delaware|New Castle County]], passing through [[Marshallton, Delaware|Marshallton]]. [[White Clay Creek]] empties into Red Clay Creek near [[Stanton, Delaware|Stanton]],<ref name=boyd1874/> approximately {{convert|5|mi}} southwest of [[Wilmington, Delaware|Wilmington]]. Ultimately, Red Clay Creek enters the Christiana River, also near Stanton.<ref name=boyd1874/> ==Tributaries== * Calf Run, located in the southeast of [[Mill Creek Hundred]]<ref name=boyd1874/> * Pyle's Run, located in [[Christiana Hundred]]<ref name=boyd1874/> ==History== The creek serves as a boundary between the [[Hundred (county subdivision)|Hundreds]] of [[Mill Creek Hundred|Mill Creek]] and [[Christiana Hundred|Christiana]].<ref name=boyd1874/> The [[Wilmington and Western Railroad]] follows the creek south from [[Yorklyn, Delaware|Yorklyn]] as far as [[Greenbank, Delaware|Greenbank]]. In the late 19<sup>th</sup> Century, several factories were located along Red Clay Creek, including those for the manufacture of [[Gristmill|flour]], [[wool]] and [[Ironworks|iron]].<ref name=boyd1874/> The creek suffered from severe flooding in 1999 due to [[Hurricane Floyd]] and in 2003 due to [[2003 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Henri|Tropical Storm Henri]]. Since 2000, portions of the river, along with other tributaries of White Clay Creek, have been protected as part of the [[White Clay Creek Wild and Scenic River]]. ==Bridges== * [[Ashland Covered Bridge]], in New Castle County, Delaware<ref name="nris">{{NRISref|version=2010a}}</ref> * [[Wooddale Bridge]], in New Castle County, Delaware<ref name="nris"/> ==See also== *[[List of Delaware rivers]] *[[List of rivers of Pennsylvania]] ==References== {{Reflist|refs= <ref name=NHD>U.S. Geological Survey.
